title: Is there a way to measure or count the amount of time we are logged on ruqqus?

author.bio:
I like photos of our amazing planet and beyond.
I'm guildmaster of two guilds.
+newsinpictures - get the news in pictures instead of articles.
+MacOS - everything about Apple's desktop OS, MacOS.
author.bio_html: I like photos of our amazing planet and beyond. I'm guildmaster of two guilds. +newsinpictures - get the news in pictures instead of articles. +MacOS - everything about Apple's desktop OS, MacOS.

body:
I don't think there is a first party way but there should be a fair amount of time tracking extensions for your browser.
Even then, I really dont want to see how much of my life I am wasting :P
body_html: I don't think there is a first party way but there should be a fair amount of time tracking extensions for your browser. Even then, I really dont want to see how much of my life I am wasting :P

guild.description:
The official guild for all things Ruqqus.

Rules:

💻 No promotion of other sites that aren't a fork of Ruqqus

🟪 Ruqqus-related only. This is a community dedicated to Ruqqus meta discussion. Content may involve technology and politics but must have ample context in Ruqqus.

📬 No spamming. Spamming comments or posts is not allowed.

😀 Be civil. Be nice. Harassment, trolling, and disruptive behavior is not allowed. Basically, don’t be a jerk.

📜 Follow Ruqqus ToS. This is a given.

For press releases, visit +RuqqusPress.

For updates and patch notes, visit +changelog.

For ideas and feedback, visit +BetaFeedback

For bug reports, visit +RuqqusBugs

guild.name: Ruqqus

post.title: Is there a way to measure or count the amount of time we are logged on ruqqus?

body: The problem with this idea is that there is no way for the server to tell when someone left. There's no long-running connection between a user and ruqqus.com, so the best thing you could do is start a timer every time a user request a page, and stop it when it reaches, say, 5 minutes since the last request. But that isn't perfect as the user may be reading a particularly long comment. Conversely, they may just be dropping by to check their inbox, which would add 5 minutes to their time even though they left immediately after.
body_html: The problem with this idea is that there is no way for the server to tell when someone left. There's no long-running connection between a user and ruqqus.com, so the best thing you could do is start a timer every time a user request a page, and stop it when it reaches, say, 5 minutes since the last request. But that isn't perfect as the user may be reading a particularly long comment. Conversely, they may just be dropping by to check their inbox, which would add 5 minutes to their time even though they left immediately after.
